image.title: World News, Today World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News, Trending News of World - Times of India

item.title: Frederick Forsyth Death: 10 remarkable facts about the master storyteller—that seem fake
item.description: Forsyth’s life was as compelling as his fiction: a Royal Air Force pilot, a war reporter censored by the BBC, an MI6 asset, and a bestselling novelist whose understanding of realpolitik was sharp enough to worry governments. He wrote thrillers, yes—but thrillers with classified undertones.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Las Vegas Strip shooting: Two people shot dead; police believe attack was targeted
item.description: A shooting near the Bellagio fountains on the Las Vegas Strip resulted in two fatalities. Police suspect 41-year-old Manuel Ruiz, who surrendered to authorities, targeted the victims following a social media dispute. The victims and suspect were known to each other, and the shooting is considered an isolated incident, not a random act of violence.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Los Angeles protests: Why are Waymo robotaxis being torched? At least five self-driving cars destroyed in riots
item.description: Amidst tense protests in Los Angeles following immigration raids, several Waymo self-driving taxis were vandalized and set ablaze. Demonstrators, expressing anger towards law enforcement and perceived Big Tech inequality, targeted the robotaxis. At least five Waymo vehicles were destroyed, raising safety concerns due to burning lithium-ion batteries releasing toxic gases.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Pro-family initiative': Donald Trump announces $1,000 government-funded accounts for American babies — who qualifies for the scheme?
item.description: Donald Trump has introduced a federal initiative to bolster financial security for future generations, proposing $1,000 investment accounts for American babies born between 2025 and 2029. Dubbed "Trump accounts," these tax-deferred investments would track stock market performance and allow additional contributions.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Clean sweep needed': RFK Jr fires vaccine advisory board; AMA calls move 'undermining trust'
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. dismissed all members of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, sparking criticism from medical organizations like the AMA and APHA. Kennedy justified the decision by citing conflicts of interest and the need to restore public confidence in vaccine science.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump-Musk thaw: President says he won't dump his Tesla, nor get rid of Starlink at the White House
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Saudi Arabia resumes Umrah visa issuance from June 10: What pilgrims need to know
item.description: Saudi Arabia will resume issuing Umrah visas starting June 10, 2025, welcoming international pilgrims from June 11. This follows a successful Hajj season that hosted over 1.6 million pilgrims. The Ministry of Hajj and Umrah instructed Umrah companies to finalize service agreements by May 27 to ensure coordinated pilgrim services.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US Navy bans dog and cat experiments following White Coat Waste Project advocacy
item.description: The White Coat Waste Project exposed a Navy-funded lab conducting painful experiments on cats, including disabled ones, sparking public outrage. Following relentless investigation and a public campaign, the US Navy has officially banned all dog and cat experiments. This decision marks the end of a painful chapter of government-funded animal abuse, celebrated by animal rights groups like PETA.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'LA would have been completely obliterated': Trump justifies deploying National Guard in California; says governor should 'thank' him
item.description: Donald Trump defended his choice to send National Guard to California due to Los Angeles riots. He criticised Governor Gavin Newscom and Mayor Karen Bass. Protests erupted over Trump's immigration policies, leading to clashes. Demonstrators damaged property and blocked roads. Newsom plans to sue the Trump administration over the deployment. Many arrests happened in Los Angeles. The city faced destruction.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump vs Musk: Billionaire investor Michael Moritz' advice to Silicon Valley, 'One of them is a medical monarch...'

item.title: World’s highest metro station to be built on Dubai’s new blue line
item.description: Dubai is poised to break another record with the Dubai Metro Blue Line, featuring the world's highest metro station at 74 metres. Designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the Emaar Properties Station will accommodate 160,000 passengers daily. This expansion will increase the metro network to 131 km with 78 stations, supporting Dubai's growing ridership and mobility masterplan.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Just a bunch of people having fun watching cars burn': ABC News reporter slammed for his description of LA riots
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: America burning: LA reels under anti-immigration protests for third straight day despite Trump's National Guard order
item.description: Downtown Los Angeles is facing escalating unrest as protests against President Trump's immigration policies turned violent, leading to clashes between demonstrators and law enforcement. The deployment of the National Guard without the governor's consent has intensified tensions, resulting in numerous arrests and widespread damage. The city is now at a critical juncture, grappling with federal intervention and escalating civil strife.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Elon's scuffle with Bessent: Steve Bannon says it was the day Musk was microdosing; 'If you lay hands on Scott...'
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: If It Happened There: Donald Trump sends central troops to quell protests in opposition-ruled California
item.description: ​Mr Trump – known for strongman-like tendencies like Mr Putin and Mr Jinping – sent in over 2,000 National Guard troops, dressed like Stormtroopers, to quell a popular uprising sparked by workplace raids on labourers who Mr Trump’s officials claim are “illegals” working in America without papers. It was, as one expert put it, a prime example of authoritarian overreach that has become a feature of American autocracy since Mr Trump’s white nationalist Republican Party came to power in the last election.
item.dc:creator: Nirmalya Dutta
